course.name: A storm in a teacup
course.meaning: a lot of unnecessary anger and worry about a matter that is not important
course.example: She’s made an official complaint to the CEO about the type of cheese in the cheese sandwiches at the canteen. This seems to me to be a storm in a teacup

course.name: Bob’s your uncle!
course.meaning: "and there it is" or "and there you have it"
course.example: To make a cup of mint tea; boil a kettle, add a tea bag, wait 2 minutes and Bob's your uncle

course.name: As dead as a doornail!
course.example: I tried to save the mouse that my cat brought in, but it was as dead as a doornail

course.name: To kick the bucket
course.example: Unfortunately, our favourite neighbour kicked the bucket 3 years ago, but we still feel her presence in the neighbourhood

course.name: Everything but the kitchen sink
course.example: Will packs lightly for travel, but I throw everything but the kitchen sink into my suitcase

course.name: The lights are on, but nobody’s home
course.meaning: used to say that somebody is stupid, even though they look normal
course.example: Jennifer has a degree in interior design, but the lights are on and nobody’s home

course.name: Donkey’s years
course.meaning: used to describe an action that has continued for a very long time
course.example: Will’s lived in the countryside for donkey’s years - he wouldn’t survive in a city

course.name: To do a runner
course.meaning: to leave a place in order to avoid a difficult or unpleasant situation or to avoid paying for something
course.example: They ordered the caviar, but when the bill arrived they did a runner

course.name: Nothing to write home about
course.example: I met a boy at the ice rink, but he’s nothing to write home about. The meal was nice, but it was nothing to write home about

course.name: Keep your eyes peeled!
course.meaning: keep your eyes open or be vigilant
course.example: Keep your eyes peeled for green scarves. Keep your eyes peeled for any calendars with chickens on the

course.name: To pick someone’s brain
course.meaning: obtain information by questioning someone who is well informed on that particular subject
course.example: Colin! I need to pick your brain about the new project

course.name: To put (the) feelers out
course.meaning: to make informal suggestions as a way of testing other people's opinions on something before any decisions are made
course.example: Can I suggest that we put feelers out to see if the employees actually want an office party on zoom this year

course.name: The best thing since sliced bread!
course.meaning: that something is the best and most useful innovation of recent times
course.example: When flip phones came out I thought they were the best thing since sliced bread! I miss hanging up so sassily

course.name: Take a chill pill!
course.example: At the picnic, I told Mary to take a chill pill as she was freaking out about a wasp.

course.name: I’ll show myself out
course.meaning: Used when you have disgraced yourself, to save someone else from having to ‘show you the door’
course.example: What’s the difference between snowmen and snowwomen? Snowballs! I’ll see myself out

course.question: What is Bob's your uncle means?

answers.answer: There you have it/ there it is

course.question: What is a storm in a teacup means?

answers.answer: There is a storm in your tea

course.question: I left my money at home. Let's leave quickly to avoid paying the bill!
